name: Rosemary
climate: Rosemary thrives in a Mediterranean climate with mild, wet winters and hot, dry summers.
It prefers conditions where the temperature does not drop much below freezing.
Rosemary should be kept out of extremely humid conditions to prevent root rot and disease.
This plant is adapted to regions that experience long periods of drought and plenty of sunshine.
sunlight: Rosemary requires at least six to eight hours of full sunlight each day to grow properly.
Ensure rosemary is placed in a location where it receives maximum sunlight exposure.
Insufficient sunlight can lead to poor growth and legginess in rosemary plants.
Optimal growth for rosemary occurs in bright and sunny locations where it can thrive.
watering: Rosemary prefers to dry out between waterings and is quite drought-tolerant.
Overwatering can lead to root rot; ensure soil is well-drained and not waterlogged.
Water rosemary thoroughly but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry completely before rewatering.
During the dormant winter months, reduce watering frequency significantly for rosemary.
soil: Rosemary grows best in light, sandy, or loamy soils that have excellent drainage.
Avoid clay soils as they retain too much moisture, which can harm rosemary roots.
A slightly acidic to neutral pH is ideal, maintaining around a pH level of 6 to 7.
To improve drainage, consider adding coarse sand or grit to the soil when planting rosemary.
extra_care_tip: Prune rosemary regularly to encourage bushy growth and to prevent it from becoming too woody.
In colder climates, rosemary can be grown in pots and brought indoors during winter.
Frost protection is essential if growing rosemary outdoors in regions with harsh winters.
To enhance flavor and aroma, harvest rosemary leaves in the morning once the dew has dried.
